column2: Figure 8.8 ODA per capita volatility to selected long-term fragile states, 2005–2013
Development Initiatives based on FFP Fragile States Index, OECD DAC and World Bank.
ODA excludes debt relief and humanitarian assistance.
Bullet points on data and charts:
Aid shock - defined as a change of more than 15% in ODA per capita from one year to another.
Aid shocks as defined in GHA 2015 refer to ODA per capita (less debt relief and humanitarian assistance).

Aid shocks occur with relative frequency in both fragile states and non-fragile states. Between 2005 and 2013 only 5 countries did not record at least one aid shock (the 5 countries were all fragile states).
20 out of 70 2013 fragile states recorded 4 or more aid shocks over period 2005-2013, of which 4 recorded 6 or more aid shocks.

Figure 8.c.i highlights the volatility in ODA per capita to four long term fragile states; Côte d'Ivoire, Egypt, Eritrea and Zimbabwe. All four countries received an aid shock in 6 or more years over 8 year period 2005-2013, Egypt recorded an aid shock in every year over the period.
Figure 8.c.ii highlights the volatility in ODA per capita to 4 fragile states; all 4 countries received an aid shock in 6 or more years over the 8 year period 2005-2013.

Figure 8.c.iii follows the trends in ODA per capita to Iraq and Myanmar. Iraq, a long term fragile state records an aid shock in every year between 2005 and 2013, aside from the ODA per capita increase over 2012-2013, all other aid shocks over the period are negative as Iraq sees ODA per capita decrease over time. On the other hand, ODA per capita in Myanmar remains low until an increase 2012-2013 (a factor of 8.8 increase in ODA per capita as compared to the previous year).
